Despite what others say, this game is pretty decent. No I probably wouldn't buy it full price unless you absolutely love anything Star Wars. I view this game in a similar way people view Hogwarts Legacy. Some people love that game because it takes place in their favorite universe and lets them play a video game for that setting. Some people hate that game due to maybe the combat, story, critic reviews, etc. Some people will still play the game despite what others think of it being a "bad game". 

But as I said, if you like Star Wars, have some extra cash to spend (whether full price or on sale), and want a decent story game I would recommend this game.

There's a lot of story in this game but it does require some patience as with a lot of stealth mercenary like games. I very much enjoyed the game and think that its an excellent edition to the Star Wars canon. It tells a pretty captivating story with new intriguing characters and while I will admit it has its faults I genuinely enjoyed the game and would recommend it.

Journey to a galaxy far, far away and play as Kay Vess, a freelancer who is willing to do almost any job if the credits are right. She'll use her skills to try to survive the syndicate underworld in Star Wars: Outlaws. You'll be zooming around the galaxy trying to hire a crew for a huge heist job, perhaps the biggest score of anyone’s life. The problem is that to get the best crew you’re going to have to jump through some serious hoops to convince them to join you.

This game definitely has plenty to keep you busy with when it comes to the puzzle aspects. You will be splicing into computer systems to open doors, turn off security cameras, clear your wanted status with the Empire, and more. You’re also going to have to electric lockpick, by rhythm, your way through doors, systems, and locked chests. The game will have some required upgrades for those two systems so you’ll be forced to come back to certain areas/planets.

You’re also going to have to deal with 4 different syndicate factions. These factions, if you’re in their good graces, will give you access to certain perks such as discounts and faction specific equipment. If you’ve ever played against rival organizations you’ll know that you can’t make EVERYONE happy, your actions for one group is going to make another angry. If you do enough to a certain group they will try to kill you on sight ANYTIME you’re even close by. I personally learned that the hard way when it came to The Pykes (ironically one of the very first syndicates you’re introduced to in the game). 

Let’s talk about combat real quick. There’s really two forms of combat you’ll be partaking in, the 3rd person shooter variety and the space craft kind. When it comes to the 3PS version you’ll have to be fast on your feet aiming for the head, and praying that you don’t take too much damage. You do have health bars, and as long as there is still a bit in one bar it can, potentially, heal back to full, but if you’re getting clobbered you’re going to have to use your very limited Bacta Vials to try to bring you back from the edge of death. You’ll be armed with a blaster that you can upgrade as you go through the game, it comes with 3 different shooting modes, and it will be your task to make sure you’re proficient in all 3 and know when it is best to use them. There will also be chances to pick up certain dropped weapons that have a limited amount of ammo that you can use to defeat your enemies.

Now let’s talk about ship combat, something that until I had most of my ship parts upgraded to close to maximum, I was terrible at. For the most part this form of combat is not going to play that big of a role in the overall game, but there are definitely going to be some situations where you’re going to have to survive through waves of enemy ships, and if you’re not careful you’re going to have quite a few game over moments. You’ll have 3 attack options by the end of the game, and to be honest I think I really only used the lasers and on REALLY rare occasions I’d remember that I had rockets, which never really did enough (in my honest opinion).

This game has enough content that you can easily go over 28 hours. I know that because that’s exactly what I did. It pays to explore every area you come upon, you’ll find hidden areas that can give you rare parts, or just give you more credits. Speaking of credits, let me give you some sage advice: If you think you have stockpiled enough credits, you haven’t. Some of the upgrades that you have to make to your Speeder (think hoverbike) or your ship will clean you out. Not only do you need to collect all the parts, but it's going to cost you to complete the upgrade. Another bit of advice is that if there is something that is highlighted as something you can pick up, pick it up, you’re going to need that constant stream of junk that you can sell to vendors to keep your pockets somewhat filled.

One of my favorite mechanics in this game, and I’ve been saving for one of my final paragraphs, is Nix. Nix is a Merqaal and is your character’s most trusted companion (sidenote, trust is a concept that is going to be all over the place throughout the entire game… except when it comes to Nix). You can use Nix to distract enemies, push buttons, sabotage security systems, attack enemies, and in stressful times give you a little cuteness to calm you down. There are also food vendors on each planet that you visit that if you have the credits you can trigger a quick time event with Nix and both of you will be able to enjoy a new exotic meal together. Those meals will also unlock special abilities for Nix, so you should seriously make sure you get all the food vendors.

I really liked the game, I played it for 24 hours straight (it was for Extra Life), but even if I wasn’t playing for charity I’d still have put in the hours that I did so that I could play the game from start to finish. The only thing that bugged me about the game, and I’m hoping it was just me, was the random game crashes where the game would just freeze and I would have to restart the game. Thankfully the autosave feature is pretty solid so I never really had to backtrack too much in order to be right back to where I was in the game. If you’re looking for a solid action adventure game set in the Star Wars galaxy I truly believe that you’ll want to have this game in your library.

It's a great game on it's own - both the blaster-play and the stealth mechanics are a really fun time, and it's very much a true-to-form Star Wars game at that. The part that shines the most is the Sabaac minigame which is in of itself an absolutely stellar take on Texas Hold 'Em Poker in the Star Wars universe and I hope other games adopt it.

It's Star Wars. It's a fun game. The plot is interesting in its own right, and Kay Vess has to make some genuinely tough decisions with no clear answers (it's not a good/evil dichotomy). I highly recommend it.

I loved this game and I am only a casual Star Wars fan but it's just very fun to play. Usually, mini-games aren't my thing but the Sabacc take on Texas Hold'Em Poker is perfect and I found myself just playing Sabacc. Plus, juggling your rep with the various factions was a suitable challenge to me. The puzzles were also challenging but not too difficult. Stealth mechanics were on point too.

Kay Vess is a very well rounded character and the other characters support her well. This feels like everything I'd want in a Star Wars game if I were a massive fan.

The game isn't that bad as it was described at first. I didn't encounter any bugs and the optimization is ok. I prefer this instead of SW Jedi Survivor which I find it very boring because of much puzzles even I like the lightsaber idea more.

Nails the star wars feeling better than almost any other. Amazing art direction from the way cities and cantinas feel to the typography in menus. Fun combat and exploration. Riding a speeder across the map is never not fun. Unfairly maligned at launch.

Since Disney took over the franchise this is the only game which comes close to one of my absolute favorite Star Wars games, Dark Forces.  I think the devs did a great job at creating a game which makes you feel like a small time petty thief who stumbles into a story a little larger than themselves.  Key Vess is an enjoyable protagonist and I like that she is presented as basically being a noob who is constantly in over her head backed up by some great voice acting.  The supporting cast are all entertaining as well and I especially enjoyed ND-5's story arc (though I think his jacket is kind of stupid looking).   The plot itself isn't anything revolutionary but it's functional and presented well enough.  Even though this game isn't an RPG there is still a system of skill progression you unlock by getting to know various experts and I absolutely LOVE this system and it reminds me a bit of the first Division game (which I also loved).  There's just...a lot to love here.

Graphics-wise this is a very pretty game and Massive's Snowdrop engine really shines here.  Everything looks grungy and lived in and really gives you the feel of being in your own Star Wars story.  On the flip side Imperial facilities are very clean and shiny looking.  Photomode is included so you can take great shots of this wonderful engine in action.

As for negatives it has me asking the question, "why is this an open world game?" often enough but I think they just scrape by in justifying it, as it has you searching the world for goodies and experts to learn new skills from.  The other big negative for me is that mechanics across the board have been done better in other games and are simply good enough here.  Controls can be a bit awkward leading you to commit actions you had no intention of doing from time to time.  The positive to that all of these 6/10 systems come together and gel into an 8/10 game for me.

I originally played this game on Uplay+ so I can also say mechanically this game has come a long way and the most obvious change happened with the speeder controls.  They were serviceable in their original incarnation but are quite elegant today by comparison.  A number of systems have been improved since release so now is really the time to dive in and enjoy all the wonderful refinements for the first time if you haven't already.

In short: it looks great, game mechanics have improved over time, and the sum of the game is greater than its individual parts.  If you're a fan of Star Wars, old or new, do yourself a favor and pick this game up.

If you’re thinking about picking up this game, I’d say go for it but grab it on discount. It’s not a flawless experience, and it definitely doesn’t justify the full price, but it is truly a good game.
The characters are genuinely fun, the stealth-focused gameplay feels great if you enjoy sneaking around, and the world is enjoyable to explore. Kay is a fun protagonist just trying to survive and making mistakes along the way. ND-5 and Nix also add a lot of personality and charm to the adventure. The other shipmates are background characters basically.
The story won’t change your life, the maps are very good but all space sections are tiny and it would've been better if they were merged into a bigger interesting location, but the overall available parts of the galaxy are still entertaining. If you like the crime side of Star Wars or enjoy stealth-driven games, this one is absolutely worth grabbing, when it’s on sale.

After not enjoying it initially, I've revisited it after several gameplay updates and I gotta give this one a thumbs up.  I'm a sucker for the "stealth until you can't" 3rd person style game, and this one has a lots of tools to help keep stealth interesting and save your ass in a pinch. 

Once combat starts, I found the shooting very satisfying. Switching up your blaster mod, trying to do a super reload and making sure your cover isn't getting compromised is a very fun combat loop.  Dangerous enemies are notated and their big attacks are telegraphed. Grenade launchers and snipers are especially deadly.  Picking up unused weapons and firing it until its empty was always fun and worth it and it happens all the time.

Getting good and learning how to cheat at Sabacc was rewarding, fun and not easy.  The whole way the game presents Sabacc, teaches it to you, then rewards you for it was excellent. For reference, Fallout New Vegas is one of my most played games and I've not once gave a damn about caravan, or that Witcher card one either.  Gambling and card games are not my usual jam but this one struck a chord with me.

The atmosphere is amazing. The cities are packed and interesting, there's lots to notice, lots of intel leads to explore. there is plenty of content packed most places there is significant population. Exploration of densely packed places is rewarding.  The open areas of wilderness are also beautiful and interesting.  Getting chased by imperials in speeders with tie fighters flying overhead and hearing the imperial chatter regarding your actions was some of the best organic non-scripted moments for me, personally.

Space combat and travel was fun, albeit a bit shallow.  Was fun upgrading systems and watching my ship start being able to take hits and then eventually learning how to avoid the hits altogether. It culminates well into the final mission ala classic Star Wars. In fact, the final mission was one of the best in the game. 

I love the game economy. I never felt like I had too much money because everything I had needed upgrading.  Some parts are hard to find, some are expensive.  You get into the habit of keeping an eye out for what you need and the store menus and UI are a huge help with keeping track.  Honestly, having to buy or barter with different vendors all around for specific, expensive, or rare parts felt very Star Wars to me.

What the Luke Skywalker Fantasy is To Jedi Fallen Order,   the Han Solo fantasy is to Star Wars: Outlaws.
I think game is worth for Sabacc alone. I need it to get a separate game like Gwent did.

I feel like this game is underrated and over hated. It's not worth the full price and should be bought on a discount. It does have some flaws. It's not perfect by any means. 

BUT, it is a good game! The characters are pretty awesome. ND-5 is such an awesome droid. I think Kay is a very likeable protagonist. She's flawed and imperfect, often lucking her way through situations and crossing the wrong people - But that adds value to her character in my opinions, I love that she isn't perfect. 

The story isn't groundbreaking, but it's a good ride! I'm a stealth sucker, so the gameplay is right up my alley for infiltration and the likes. Your speeder and ship are great personal additions and while the space gameplay isn't amazing, it's still better than Starfield and overall fun! 

Nix (your little pet) is an absolute treasure! He's by far the best addition to the game. He's so lovable and extremely useful! I adore both his personality and his gameplay mechanics. 

Like I said: The game isn't perfect and is too expensive at full price. But at a discount, this is a really fun game for those who enjoy the crime side of Star Wars or stealth based games.

My take on Star Wars Outlaws so far

I’m not very far into the game yet — but even so, the story and world-building have been very well done. The setting feels immersive, the factions add meaningful variety, and there’s a sense that you can tackle missions in multiple ways depending on your style. When you sneak around, use stealth takedowns, or try to bluff your way through — that’s where the game really shines.

That said… if you go in wanting to be a brawler or “guns-blazing” type, Outlaws doesn’t always deliver. My character often feels weak — like there’s no weight behind the blaster-shots or melee hits. Combat works okay in short bursts, but unlike stealthy, calculated infiltration, it rarely feels satisfying.

So far, I’m enjoying Outlaws most when I embrace the sneaky scoundrel vibe. If that’s not your thing, I can see how it might feel underwhelming. All in all: a strong, atmospheric Star Wars experience — but not always the “shoot-first, ask questions later” adventure some might expect.

The game play is quite fun and I'm enjoying the adventure. I'd say if you're a fan of Star Wars or open world adventure games, you'll likely enjoy this one.

10/10 would pet Nix again. An open world space adventure that truly captures the spirit of the galaxy far far away. Each planet feels alive. Joined every syndicate clan, still broke but stylishly! Lots of missions maybe even too many. but hey, not complaining. Epic game, pure Star Wars magic!

I especially love Kijimi City! cloaked in frozen streets and filled with an unforgettable underworld atmosphere <3

A fantastic Star Wars experience. The open-world design works really well here, and I loved exploring different planets while getting into all kinds of trouble as Kay Vess. The story is engaging, the characters are fun, and the game really nails that Star Wars atmosphere. Easily one of the better Star Wars games in years.

GET IT.

This game is a fantastic open world Star Wars game, with unique planets and characters. I'm not sure what they changed from launch to now but the game is really fun currently with very few issues that I've encountered.

It's not a perfect game by any means, but it's pretty fun. The first couple of hours I wasn't sure if I'd like the game or not, but once you can finally get off planet and fly around in your ship and the world opens up to you a bit it does get better. 

The environments look amazing, and overall the game runs well. There are some clipping issues that you'll see from time to time which is annoying but it's not like it's the end of the world. 

However I do have to compare the game to Jedi Survivor, since it's another major SW title that released just a year prior and that I played 5 months ago, Outlaws runs significantly better and it's not even a contest. Although personally I find that Jedi Survivor does a much better job of feeling like a Star Wars game, whereas Outlaws could easily be it's own IP if you just switch up all the aliens to new species and change a few other things. Idk if that's subconcious thing about playing as a Jedi vs just a normal human making me feel that way or just the overall atmosphere of the game, but that's just the feeling I get when playing it. 

My biggest complaint about the game would have to be the speed in which Kay Vess walks/runs. The speed in which she walks reminds me of being stuck behind one of these a**holes in a grocery store with zero sense of spacial awareness that walks perfectly down the middle of the aisle so you can't get around them as they walk about 30% slower than your normal pace. 

Overall I'd say it's a 7/10, and worth buying on sale. Particularly if you enjoy the standard Ubisoft game structure.

Recommended (on sale, if you’re a Star Wars nerd)

I’m a Star Wars geek. I like pretty much all things Star Wars. Do I wish there was more content like Andor and less like The Last Jedi? Yes. Very much yes.

Is Star Wars Outlaws great? It’s… alright. Not terrible, not amazing, just very okay.
The story missions are fine, the story itself is fine, but nothing grabbed me in a “wow, I can’t wait to replay this” way. A lot of the time it felt like I was playing a more linear Uncharted-style platformer, just dressed up in Star Wars.

The semi-open worlds are decent, but I really wish the game leaned more into a GTA/Assassin’s Creed–style open world instead of “here’s your little sandbox between story corridors.” Cosmetics felt pretty lame, and unlocking blaster parts was tedious and not very creative. It’s got that typical Ubisoft feel: competent, polished enough, but very safe.

The graphics are solid, exactly what you’d expect from Ubisoft on a big licensed title but what I’m still waiting for is a deep Star Wars RPG. Something that mixes old-school Star Wars Galaxies and KOTOR with modern tech and lets us fully live out the fantasy:
being a nobody on Tatooine who turns into a lightsaber-wielding, blaster-toting, spaceship-flying, scruffy-looking nerf herder.

If you really like Star Wars, grab it on sale and enjoy wandering around the galaxy for a bit. If you’re looking for a groundbreaking game or a truly deep RPG? This isn’t that one.

Wow. What a refreshing and great take on the Star Wars universe. Taking place between Empire and Return of the Jedi, you play as Kay Vess, up and coming smuggler and criminal who has to build her reputation throughout the underworld. Eventually you're recruited to do a grand heist where you need to assemble a team of experts in order to break into a nearly impenetrable vault.
The gameplay and atmosphere and world building and interactions with characters are all sensational, when I landed on Tatooinee and started exploring I literally felt like I was in a playable version of the original Star Wars movie (A New Hope). 
It's so so so so refreshing to NOT play as a force wielder and just be a normal ass person trying to make their way in the Galaxy. People have 0 respect or love for you and it's really cool to see the day to day interactions of the various nobodies in the Star Wars universe. It's extremely believable too that Kay is super inexperienced and new to all of this so you're learning right alongside her.
The story was fantastic, the last mission had me genuinely feeling PTSD and the DLCs were great as well. Special shout out to the second DLC featuring the almighty Hondo Ohnaka. I found myself dying of laughter at several of his voice lines.

All and all it's just an amazing game and the fact that there would've been a sequel kills me. There needs to be more to Kay Vess' story down the line

TLDR: Lots of potential, but sadly it will likely go unrealized.

I initially bought the game on sale because I'd heard that all the bugs had been more or less ironed out, and that it had gotten the atmosphere of Star Wars right. Thankfully, I did get what I paid for, but I think there's so much that can be improved. Here are some places where I feel it has performed above my expectations, some points where I felt it fell slightly short, and some areas where I feel it is just irredeemable short of a major content update.

Pleasant surprises: 

1. When you dial enemy health up to max, stormtroopers actually feel like a menace. You have to, as Thanos says, 'go for the head', and their armor finally feels like it makes a difference in terms of stopping blaster bolts. 

2. The Empire's recruitment campaigns and canvassing is actually quite believable (sign up and make a difference!), and not at all comic-book-villain-esque (wanna be evil? Get a cool black uniform? Join us and TAKE OVER THE UNIVERSE!!!)... unlike a certain other villain that will be mentioned later.

3. The speederbike conveys the feeling of effortless, hovering speed very well.

4. Truly breathtaking scenery and epic platforming areas. Potential horror spin-off? Who knows.

5. Kay Vess's skepticism of the Rebel Alliance. 4. The first five or eight seconds of the start music is REALLY annoying. It's like they're trying to tell you 'omg, this is going to be such a frantic scrabble for survival in a fast-paced galaxy'... but it's the game's job to SHOW that. Show that in gameplay, don't TELL me that with an accomplishment in the top left corner of the screen that says 'we made it'. An example of a game franchise that does this REALLY well is the Uncharted series (especially 2 and 3). The music is grand, optimistic, and suggests a sense of awe in some places - in short, all the ingredients of an adventure. Then the game takes you and puts you through the wringer, forcing you through some genuinely frustrating and gut-wrenching moments that SHOW you Nathan Drake battling a small army. Fatal/unfixable flaws (at least not without a massive content update):

1. One of my pet peeves is that Sliro refers to himself and his rivals as being part of 'the Underworld'. Oh, come on. 13-year-olds understand that comic-book villains who prance around in black capes and say 'eeeeevill' are focused on children who are 10 and under. There are so many ways Sliro could have SHOWN the audience that he was not an upright citizen instead of telling them. He could have said something like 'you won't be arrested as long as you don't get caught', or looked over at his aide after receiving a report and said 'all right, pull the trigger - and make sure Governor Pudark gets his cut in unmarked beskar this time.' or 'that man has crossed me for the last time, make sure he's never seen again', or when someone at the table looks at him and says with a nasty grin, 'last week, a village got wiped out in the crossfire between two rival tribes - do you know something about that', he could have smiled, shrugged his shoulders, and said in the most disgustingly mock-innocent voice 'why would I know anything about tribal wars? 2. Lack of a leveling system in lieu of a deep equipment customization tree. They could fix this by letting the ability to sense people be explained by Kay Vess always having this sort of a 'sixth sense' all on her own, and later in the story have someone explain that she had SOME sensitivity in the Force, but that it wasn't strong enough for her to move objects (which would be why she needed Nyx). Then maybe at some point in the story, she could be told that she didn't really need her macrobinoculars to mark people, because her power came from the Force - and then all of a sudden for maybe a final mission, she would be able to sense everyone and everything without marking them with her macrobinoculars, and maybe manages to Force pull something tiny (but mighty enough) to take down a big baddie right at the end. [h1]Star Wars Outlaws Review[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Not perfect and very Ubisoft, but I still had a good time. If you like Star Wars and want to explore familiar planets with a grounded outlaw story, this scratches the itch. If you dislike the Ubisoft formula, this likely will not convert you.

[hr]
[h1]Story Hook[/h1]
Kay Vess pulls a heist that goes sideways and lands on the wrong lists across the Outer Rim. With Nyx at her side, she takes jobs for rival syndicates, plays factions against each other, and hunts for a way out while staying one step ahead of bounty hunters and the Empire. No Force powers, just grit, tricks, and contacts.

[hr]
[h1]What It Is[/h1]
A third person open world that sticks close to the studio playbook. Clear markers, outposts, factions, side jobs, reputation to juggle. You are not a Jedi. You are a scrappy thief working the underworld, which feels fresh for the license.

[hr]
[h1]World and Atmosphere[/h1]
Planets look great and feel lived in. Lighting, ship and armor textures, and general art direction are strong. Most areas never feel empty unless that is the point. Cruising the deserts or city edges on the bike is fun even with quirks.

[hr]
[h1]Movement and Combat[/h1]
Traversal is solid, bike riding is enjoyable but can be clunky. You will clip walls or see odd animations now and then. Gunplay is serviceable. Some melee interactions look silly, like Kay knocking out stormtroopers through helmets. It works, but it is not highly polished.

[hr]
[h1]Kay and Nyx[/h1]
Kay took time to click for me. She is fine, not a new favorite. Nyx is the star. As a companion he fetches items, distracts enemies, opens doors, and adds charm. Their partnership carries many encounters.

[hr]
[h1]Systems and Factions[/h1]
Smuggler jobs, light stealth, simple upgrades, faction standing. Plenty to do without drowning you in chores. The world usually rewards curiosity and small detours.

[hr]
[h1]Performance and Stability[/h1]
The game runs, but it is not very polished. I saw FPS dips in crowded interiors and in some open world spots. Crashes happened. Hardware helps only so much because some hitches feel engine related.

[hr]
[h1]Achievements and Completion[/h1]
Chill and straightforward. Creative objectives, little to no collectible spam, and a clear path to 100 percent. I finished in about 75 hours while taking my time. You can likely do it faster.

[hr]
[h1]DLC[/h1]
Two packs included in my run. Pirate Fortune is a short detour with a new area that I rushed since it did not grab me. Wild Card was shorter but more fun. Season pass coverage can be confusing, check your edition details before buying.

[hr]
[h1]What Works[/h1]
[list]
[*] Strong Star Wars vibe and art direction
[*] Being a non Jedi outlaw feels unique
[*] Nyx is a great companion
[*] Open worlds that invite exploration
[*] Achievement list respects your time
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]What Falls Short[/h1]
[list]
[*] Ubisoft formula fatigue if you are not into it
[*] Noticeable performance dips and some crashes
[*] Combat and melee can feel clunky
[*] Character writing for Kay is uneven
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Recommended for Star Wars fans who want a big world to explore without lightsabers. Not recommended if the Ubisoft loop turns you off or if technical polish is a hard requirement. I enjoyed it despite the rough edges, mostly because the world sells the fantasy and Nyx kept me smiling.

Star Wars Outlaws – Review

I put just under 60 hours into Star Wars Outlaws, completing nearly all of the main story and side quests I could find, apart from the Radiant contracts. With that much time invested, I can say I had a really good experience overall.

Kay Vess turned out to be a surprisingly interesting protagonist, with distinct quirks and some genuinely engaging character beats. Her story was well put together, and her interactions with notable lore figures were a highlight.

The game is packed with fun easter eggs. Boba Fett and Han Solo showing up in the Jabba’s Palace sequence was a standout moment. I also really enjoyed the chance to duel Lando in Sabacc: not just once in the main story (to unlock ability upgrades), but again in the DLC. It was a clever way to weave character-driven moments into gameplay.

Speaking of upgrades, I liked how ability progression was handled. Instead of a bland menu system, you complete small challenges to improve your skills. It made the process feel like a natural part of the adventure rather than a checklist.

The Radiant contracts did get a bit repetitive, but they never felt boring. There was always something fun about doing them.

One of the biggest wins for this game, though, was ship gameplay. It is rare for an RPG like Outlaws to actually let you fly your own ship, upgrade it, and dive into dogfights, smuggling runs, and all those quintessential “Star Wars outlaw” experiences. That feature alone made the game stand out compared to other Star Wars titles.

I also want to highlight the DLCs. Both added stories were engaging, packed with genuine emotional beats that hit exactly where they were meant to. The writing across the board, in the main game and the DLCs, was strong enough to make me feel angry, sad, and happy in all the right moments. The narrative team clearly knew what they were doing.

In the end, it is not perfect, but it delivers a strong story, solid mechanics, and that scrappy Star Wars underworld feel.

Final Score: 8/10

Star Wars Outlaws – A Casual Review

If you’ve ever dreamed of stepping into the gritty, chaotic underworld of a galaxy far, far away, Star Wars Outlaws delivers on that fantasy. It’s not perfect, and I wish there was more of it, but I had a blast.

I didn’t play the game at launch. It caught a lot of flack back then, and I was hesitant. Partly because of the criticism, partly because of the price, but honestly, I just wasn’t in the mood to be a Star Wars smuggler in August 2024. I’m glad I waited, though, because coming into it fresh, and with any early issues mostly patched up, I found myself really enjoying the ride.

Right from the get-go, the game oozes Star Wars atmosphere. The planets are exactly what you'd expect: classic Star Wars "mono-climate" zones, a snowy planet, a jungle world, a windy one, a flashy casino planet, and of course, Tatooine. Each is beautifully crafted, immersive, and full of life (or sand, in Tatooine’s case).

And it’s not just the visuals. The sights and sounds of Star Wars are absolutely spot on. From the chatter of aliens and beeping droids as you walk through a busy street, to the hum of engines, the pew-pew of blasters, and the ambient noise that fills the world, the sound design is brilliant. It doesn’t just look like Star Wars, it sounds like it too, and that really helps transport you to the galaxy far far away. You're not just observing the world, you're in it.

Space exploration? Also very cool. Most planets (except the casino world) have a space zone to explore. One looks like a space junkyard, another feels ripped straight from Solo’s Kessel Run nebula, all super atmospheric. Tatooine’s space is a bit of a letdown, but to be fair, that’s pretty accurate to how the films portray it: vast, empty, and on the edge of nowhere.

The characters are a strong point. Kay Vess is a great lead, very much her own person. She’s not trying to be Han Solo or Jyn Erso; she feels like a real character in the Star Wars universe with her own arc and personality. Her little companion Nix is adorable and genuinely useful (think Grogu meets your in-game toolkit), and I loved their dynamic. Kay’s co-pilot, a gruff separatist commando droid, plays the Chewie role with a unique twist, though I do wish he was around more during missions.

The criminal underworld vibe is a major theme, and it’s handled pretty well. Different syndicates have distinct aesthetics and personalities, though if you boil it down, they do play similarly. The reputation system is interesting but a bit too forgiving; I was expecting to make enemies along the way, but I ended up on everyone's good side. No bounty hunters chasing me after 100 hours? C’mon, I wanted that drama!

Space combat and smuggling missions are fairly simple, but the Pirate DLC spices things up. Adding cargo types makes smuggling feel more meaningful, something most Star Wars games haven’t really explored. SWTOR, for example, never gave the smuggler class this much flavor.

Outfits are surprisingly cool. Not only do they give you that “dress for the planet” vibe (snow gear on the icy world, leather jackets in the jungle, etc.), but they come with set bonuses and perks that actually affect gameplay. You can kit yourself out for stealth or go loud with grenade-boosting gear, it’s a nice, lightweight way to tweak your playstyle without needing to grind skill trees.

Speaking of skills, the “Expert” system is another neat touch. Instead of unlocking abilities through menus, you go find someone to teach you. It’s very in-universe. The skills themselves aren’t Force powers or anything flashy, but they work well for a scoundrel. I especially liked “Fast Talk,” where you can stall enemies with a quick lie before blasting them, felt super Han Solo.

Riding around on your speeder (or swoop bike, more accurately) also captures that Star Wars spirit. It’s fun, stylish, and helps keep exploration from feeling like a chore.

There are also a couple of mini-games sprinkled throughout the galaxy that I really enjoyed. Sabacc, for one, was surprisingly fun. I usually steer clear of card games in RPGs, but I ended up playing quite a few hands across the galaxy. The “cheats” system kept it interesting, and one of my highlights was facing off against Lando. Let’s just say I had a winning hand... and then, spoilers, something happened. It was great.

Even the in-game arcade machines were a fun surprise. They're styled like retro 80s games and feel like something you’d find in-universe and in real-world arcades during the original trilogy era. It’s a small thing, but it added a lot of charm and helped tie the world back to the roots of the Star Wars franchise.

And the story? Classic Star Wars. No spoilers, but it checks all the right boxes: reluctant hero on the run, a stolen ship, shootouts, quirky aliens, evil Empire entanglements, emotional beats, and a satisfying finale. It’s nothing revolutionary, but it feels like Star Wars, and that’s all I really wanted.

As someone who’s played other big open-world games like Assassin’s Creed Odyssey and Valhalla, I did find myself wishing Outlaws had more customization, more depth, and more DLC options like those games. But honestly, wanting more is probably a good sign. It means the foundation is solid. I’d rather come away from a game thinking “I wish there was more” than “that was too much.”

Final Thoughts:
Star Wars Outlaws nails the vibe. It feels like you're in the Star Wars galaxy, living a rogue's life among smugglers, scoundrels, and syndicates. Sure, I wish the world was bigger, the systems deeper, and the danger more present, but what’s here is a solid foundation and an enjoyable ride.

Score (if I had to give one): 8/10. Not flawless, but full of heart and swagger.

Visually striking, thematically hollow, narratively wasted potential.

I’ve just finished Star Wars Outlaws, and I can honestly say this game is the definition of “so close, yet so far.” Beneath the glossy visuals and cinematic presentation lies a creative tragedy: a sandbox full of missed opportunities and shallow design choices that could have made this one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made.

Let’s start with the obvious: the world is stunning. On OLED in HDR, the art direction shines — the lighting, the environments, and the sense of scale are genuinely breathtaking. There are moments that feel alive, and Massive Entertainment clearly knows how to make a planet feel like a place. The Snowdrop engine can deliver magic. But that magic quickly fades once you realize how empty the experience is beneath the surface.

The writing is serviceable at best. It’s safe, sanitized, and devoid of the grit and complexity that defines the best Star Wars stories. Every character feels like a checkbox archetype. The protagonist — an entirely new and forgettable smuggler — lacks any of the depth or charm that made figures like Han Solo or Cassian Andor resonate. Ubisoft had decades of expanded universe lore to draw from, and they chose to invent the blandest possible scenario instead.

Gameplay? Classic Ubisoft. Outposts, fetch quests, repetitive stealth sections, and “open world” exploration that feels more like a checklist than an adventure. The bones of something good are here, but the studio never commits. The story pretends to be about survival and rebellion, yet never dares to touch the philosophical heart of Star Wars — the corruption of power, the moral ambiguity of empire and rebellion, or the human cost of resistance.

It’s a shame, because this could have been so much more. Imagine a story set during the Dark Times — the fall of the Republic, the rise of the Empire — showing the galaxy’s descent into tyranny through the eyes of ordinary people. Or a game set during the Mandalorian Wars, a morally grey era of warriors and Jedi torn by duty and pride. The material is right there. Instead, Ubisoft played it safe and made another open-world checklist game with Star Wars wallpaper.

Even the technology falters. HDR is inconsistent, with strange softness and shimmering in highlights; FSR upscaling introduces noticeable artefacts, and XeSS helps but at a performance cost. The irony? The game looks better in SDR with AMD’s Radeon Image Sharpening enabled — except you can’t use it in HDR. The visual clarity on OLED is unforgiving, exposing every flaw in the engine’s upscaling and post-processing.

And yet… I still finished it. Because buried under all that mediocrity are flashes of brilliance — the art direction, the score, the occasional moment where the world feels real. When the game stops holding your hand and just lets you exist in the galaxy, you can almost see the masterpiece it could have been.

Final Verdict:
A beautiful shell with a hollow core. Ubisoft had the license, the lore, and the technology to make something truly special. Instead, they delivered a focus-tested corporate product — safe, shallow, and forgettable.

⭐ Star Wars Outlaws – 6/10

Visually striking, thematically hollow, narratively wasted potential.

I’ve just finished Star Wars Outlaws, and I can honestly say this game is the definition of “so close, yet so far.” Beneath the glossy visuals and cinematic presentation lies a creative tragedy: a sandbox full of missed opportunities and shallow design choices that could have made this one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made.

Let’s start with the obvious: the world is stunning. On OLED in HDR, the art direction shines — the lighting, the environments, and the sense of scale are genuinely breathtaking. There are moments that feel alive, and Massive Entertainment clearly knows how to make a planet feel like a place. The Snowdrop engine can deliver magic. But that magic quickly fades once you realize how empty the experience is beneath the surface.

The writing is serviceable at best. It’s safe, sanitized, and devoid of the grit and complexity that defines the best Star Wars stories. Every character feels like a checkbox archetype. The protagonist — an entirely new and forgettable smuggler — lacks any of the depth or charm that made figures like Han Solo or Cassian Andor resonate. Ubisoft had decades of expanded universe lore to draw from, and they chose to invent the blandest possible scenario instead.

Gameplay? Classic Ubisoft. Outposts, fetch quests, repetitive stealth sections, and “open world” exploration that feels more like a checklist than an adventure. The bones of something good are here, but the studio never commits. The story pretends to be about survival and rebellion, yet never dares to touch the philosophical heart of Star Wars — the corruption of power, the moral ambiguity of empire and rebellion, or the human cost of resistance.

It’s a shame, because this could have been so much more. Imagine a story set during the Dark Times — the fall of the Republic, the rise of the Empire — showing the galaxy’s descent into tyranny through the eyes of ordinary people. Or a game set during the Mandalorian Wars, a morally grey era of warriors and Jedi torn by duty and pride. The material is right there. Instead, Ubisoft played it safe and made another open-world checklist game with Star Wars wallpaper.

Even the technology falters. HDR is inconsistent, with strange softness and shimmering in highlights; FSR upscaling introduces noticeable artefacts, and XeSS helps but at a performance cost. The irony? The game looks better in SDR with AMD’s Radeon Image Sharpening enabled — except you can’t use it in HDR. The visual clarity on OLED is unforgiving, exposing every flaw in the engine’s upscaling and post-processing.

And yet… I still finished it. Because buried under all that mediocrity are flashes of brilliance — the art direction, the score, the occasional moment where the world feels real. When the game stops holding your hand and just lets you exist in the galaxy, you can almost see the masterpiece it could have been.

Final Verdict:
A beautiful shell with a hollow core. Ubisoft had the license, the lore, and the technology to make something truly special. Instead, they delivered a focus-tested corporate product — safe, shallow, and forgettable.

6/10 – “The Force was there, but management said no.”
